tips.title: Cyber Safety Tips
tips.phishing: Never click suspicious links or share OTPs.
tips.passwords: Use strong, unique passwords and enable two-factor authentication.
tips.updates: Keep your apps and devices updated.
tips.wifi: Avoid using public Wi-Fi for sensitive transactions.
tips.sharing: Be cautious while sharing personal information online.

education.title: Cybersecurity Awareness
education.intro: Learn about different types of cyber threats and how to protect yourself.

phishing.title: Phishing
phishing.description: Phishing is a scam where attackers trick you into sharing sensitive information such as passwords, OTPs, or bank details.
phishing.example: Example: Fake email pretending to be your bank asking for login details.
phishing.prevention: Never click on suspicious links or share personal details via email or SMS.

malware.title: Malware
malware.description: Malware is harmful software designed to damage your device or steal information.
malware.example: Example: A free app that secretly installs spyware.
malware.prevention: Install apps only from trusted sources and keep antivirus software updated.

ransomware.title: Ransomware
ransomware.description: Ransomware locks your files and demands payment to unlock them.
ransomware.example: Example: Your computer shows a message demanding Bitcoin to access your files.
ransomware.prevention: Backup your files regularly and avoid downloading attachments from unknown senders.

identityTheft.title: Identity Theft
identityTheft.description: When attackers steal your personal data and use it to commit fraud.
identityTheft.example: Example: Someone uses your Aadhaar or PAN card to take a loan.

upiFraud.title: UPI & Payment Frauds
upiFraud.description: Scams targeting digital payments, such as fake QR codes or OTP scams.
upiFraud.example: Example: A scammer sends you a payment request instead of paying you.
upiFraud.prevention: Always verify payment requests and never share OTPs.

q1.question: What should I do if I suspect a cyber fraud?
q1.answer: Immediately stop communication, do not transfer money, and report the incident to the cybercrime helpline or portal (www.cybercrime.gov.in).

q2.question: How do I create a strong password?
q2.answer: Use a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols. Avoid common words like 'password' or '12345'.

q3.question: Is public Wi-Fi safe?
q3.answer: No. Public Wi-Fi can be insecure and hackers may steal your data. Use a VPN if you must connect.

q4.question: What is two-factor authentication?
q4.answer: It adds an extra layer of security by requiring a password and a verification code sent to your phone or email.

reporting.title: Report a Cybercrime
reporting.instructions: If you experience or suspect a cybercrime:
steps: Collect evidence like screenshots, emails, or transaction details
Do not delete suspicious messages before reporting
